title: Running a Business in the Countryside
instructions: Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. For Questions 22–35, choose from the women (A–E).

texts.content: A — Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with several employees. She notes that money was short in the beginning and clients from the local area often come to her home to collect work.

evidence.text: things were difficult in the beginning
people from the area tend to collect it from me

texts.content: B — Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She does not employ anyone and depends only on word-of-mouth recommendation rather than advertising.

C — Delia Turner makes curtains at home. She was initially short of money and suffered setbacks when the economy declined. She had to sack an employee when business slowed, a decision she found unpleasant.

evidence.text: things were difficult in the beginning
business has been hard at times

texts.content: D — Tessa Strickland runs a children's book-publishing business. She works with authors and illustrators from many continents, giving her international contacts. She has an office in London with staff and has changed roles in her company as it grew.

evidence.text: authors in East and North Africa, Australia, Eastern Europe
I do all the editing and design

texts.content: E — Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She works entirely alone and was initially short of money to set up the operation.

evidence.text: It cost an enormous amount of money to set up
